channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: Netanyahu Is Questioned a Second Time on Corruption Suspicions
item.description: Three days after a similar session, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel was questioned for five hours Thursday about potentially improper gifts and favors.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Women Defy Saudi Restrictions in Video, Striking a Nerve
item.description: In the widely circulated video, women in black niqabs and colorful dresses skateboard, ride scooters, shoot baskets and dance with swagger and confidence.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA

item.title: U.S. Lists Bin Laden’s Son as a ‘Global Terrorist’
item.description: The son, Hamza bin Laden, who has vowed to avenge his father’s death, is “actively engaged in terrorism,” the State Department said.
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN

item.title: Farmer on Trial Defends Smuggling Migrants: ‘I Am a Frenchman.’
item.description: Cédric Herrou has become something of a folk hero in France for resisting the state and taking a stand: that it is simply right to help migrants seeking a better life.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Romania Chooses Left-Leaning Government
item.media:description: The newly named Romanian prime minister, Sorin Grindeanu, fourth from left, with President Klaus Iohannis, sixth from left, after the swearing in of the new cabinet in Bucharest on Wednesday.
item.description: Sorin Grindeanu, a former minister of communications, was named prime minister, beating a candidate who would have been Romania’s first woman and first Muslim to hold that post.
item.dc:creator: KIT GILLET

item.title: Greece’s Most-Wanted Terrorist Is Arrested in Athens Suburb
item.description: Panagiota Roupa had been on the run since 2012. Her group, Revolutionary Struggle, was involved in a string of attacks, including one on the United States Embassy in Athens.
item.dc:creator: ILIANA MAGRA

item.title: Impeachment Trial of South Korea President Called Mob Justice
item.media:description: President Park Geun-hye of South Korea at a meeting with reporters in the country’s capital, Seoul, on Sunday. The Constitutional Court has until June to decide if the National Assembly’s Dec. 9 vote to impeach Ms. Park was justified.
item.media:credit: South Korean Presidency, via Associated Press
item.description: An attorney for Park Geun-hye compared her trial with those of Christ and Socrates, warning against “so-called majority opinion instigated through demagogy.”
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: With Manicures and Makeup, Japan’s ‘Genderless’ Blur Line Between Pink and Blue
item.media:description: Toman Sasaki, a so-called genderless danshi, at a Japanese shopping mall where he performed with his band, XOX, late last year.
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.description: Just as some American men have embraced makeup, young Japanese men are bending gender norms, a big step in a culture where genders hew strictly to convention.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Accused of Looting Millions, Son of African Leader Stalls Trial
item.media:description: Eleven cars, including two Ferraris, owned by Teodoro Nguema Obiang Mangue were seized in November by the Swiss authorities.
item.description: The son, Teodoro Nguema Obiang Mangue of Equatorial Guinea, faces 10 years in prison if he is found guilty in his trial, now delayed until June.
item.dc:creator: MARTIN DE BOURMONT

item.title: Hymn of Peace by Nigerian Leaders Strikes Some as Off Key
item.description: People expressed dismay at a gathering that included several ex-military rulers, and leaders that some partly blamed for corruption, misrule and instability.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Ex-Haiti Rebel Leader Wanted in US Arrested During Talk Show
item.description: A former rebel leader who is wanted on U.S. drug charges, and was recently elected to the Haitian Senate, was arrested Thursday as he appeared on a live radio talk show.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Trump and U.N. Leader Discuss ‘Cooperation’
item.media:description: The United Nations secretary general, António Guterres, at the organization’s headquarters in New York on Tuesday. A United Nations spokesman said Mr. Guterres initiated a phone call with President-elect Donald J. Trump on Wednesday.
item.description: A spokesman for the new secretary general, António Guterres, said that a phone call between the two men “went quite well,” though he did not elaborate on what they spoke about.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

item.title: Mexico’s New Foreign Minister Was Advocate of Visit by Donald Trump
item.media:description: President Enrique Peña Nieto of Mexico, left, on Wednesday with Luis Videgaray, his new foreign minister, in Mexico City.
item.description: Luis Videgaray had resigned his previous cabinet post after championing Mr. Trump’s enormously unpopular visit to Mexico City last year.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: What in the World: As the E.U.’s Language Roster Swells, So Does the Burden
item.description: The European Union spends about $1 billion a year on services related to its 24 official languages. Some want to add Turkish — and perhaps drop English.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER

item.title: Can a Satire of ISIS Possibly Be Funny? BBC Viewers Are Split
item.media:description: A darkly comic BBC sketch has set off a debate on the limits of satire.
item.description: “The Real Housewives of ISIS,” a sketch on the BBC Two show “Revolting,” spurred a debate on the boundaries of satire.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Nigeria Finds Chibok Girl Kidnapped by Boko Haram, With Baby
item.description: Soldiers interrogating captured Boko Haram suspects have found one of the Chibok schoolgirls kidnapped by the insurgents nearly three years ago, along with her baby, Nigeria's military said Thursday.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: 2 Officers Get Life Prison in 1st Turkish Coup Convictions
item.description: A court in eastern Turkey has sentenced two former military officers to life terms in prison, in the first convictions over the failed military coup in July.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Turkey: Suspected Kurdish Militants Kill 2 in a Car Bombing in Izmir
item.description: Suspected Kurdish militants clashed with police and detonated a car bomb in western Turkey after their vehicle was stopped at a checkpoint, killing a police officer and a court employee.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: China, Seeking to Stop Weakening of Currency, Issues Restrictions
item.media:description: A small pool of offshore renminbi trades more freely in Hong Kong, above, than in mainland China. After a two-day rally, the offshore renminbi rose as much as 2.5 percent to 6.7853 against the dollar on Thursday, an exceptional gain for a currency that is usually subject to staid trading.
item.description: Financial regulators appear to have become more concerned in recent weeks about the pace of the renminbi’s depreciation.
item.dc:creator: NEIL GOUGH

item.title: I Was in the Motorcade That Struck and Killed 6-Year-Old Toussaint Birwe
item.media:description: Villagers in Mokong, Cameroon, watched in April as the motorcade of Samantha Power, the United States ambassador to the United Nations, returned after one of its vehicles struck and killed Toussaint Birwe, 6.
item.description: I know what it’s like “to stand on the side of a road in your own country, watching the shiny vehicles filled with important people, encased in air conditioning, as they speed by.”
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER

item.title: Turkey Says Istanbul Nightclub Attacker Probably Uighur
item.description: The man who killed 39 people in an attack on an Istanbul nightclub on New Year's Day is probably an ethnic Uighur and Turkish security services now know where he might be hiding, Deputy Prime Minister Veysi Kaynak said on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Sinosphere: China Rates the Best Toilets for Tourists (and Tells the Laggards to Clean Up)
item.media:description: Gubei Water Town, a resort on the outskirts of Beijing, has the most exemplary restrooms, according to a list published by the China National Tourism Administration.
item.description: The country is making an effort to build, expand and renovate 100,000 toilets in scenic areas and along tourist routes.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES and RYAN MCMORROW

item.title: Wife of American Man Missing in Afghanistan Says He Was Abducted
item.media:description: Paul Overby in Kabul in 2010. Mr. Overby, a 74-year-old from Massachusetts, disappeared in May 2014.
item.description: Jane Larson, the wife of Paul Overby, said that he disappeared in May 2014 as he tried to cross into Pakistan from Khost in eastern Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: ADAM GOLDMAN

item.title: Britain Names Tim Barrow New Top Diplomat to E.U.
item.media:description: Tim Barrow, a career diplomat, in 2015. The decision by his predecessor, Ivan Rogers, to resign as Britain’s most senior envoy in Brussels set off a political dispute.
item.description: Mr. Barrow, a well-respected diplomat, was chosen a day after his predecessor, Ivan Rogers, announced his decision to quit.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: A New Casualty of Syria’s War: Drinking Water in Damascus
item.description: The Syrian capital and its vicinity have been afflicted by the loss of water for weeks, leaving taps dry and creating long lines at wells.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Mexicans Are the Nafta Winners? It’s News to Them
item.media:description: Trucks on an overpass at the World Trade International Bridge in Laredo, Tex. Goods manufactured by companies operating in both the United States and Mexico cross the border multiple times during production.
item.description: Donald J. Trump likes to say the trade pact has helped Mexico at the expense of American workers. But for many Mexicans, life is the same struggle as ever.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED and ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Bangkok Journal: Fighting Restoration by Clinging to Remnants of the Past
item.media:description: The whitewashed Fort Mahakan, built in the 18th century, is one of the oldest structures in Bangkok. Residents in the wooden village next to it have resisted for years a government order to move out and make way for a public park.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: At Fort Mahakan in Bangkok’s historic core, a deadline for eviction is approaching in a 24-year battle for the fort between the city and unyielding villagers.
item.dc:creator: SETH MYDANS

item.title: Israeli Soldier Who Shot Wounded Palestinian Assailant Is Convicted
item.media:description: The body of Abed al-Fatah al-Sharif after he was shot dead by Sergeant Azaria in the West Bank city of Hebron in March 2016.
item.description: The manslaughter verdict in a West Bank shooting highlighted the rifts the case has opened among Israelis and the host of political and ethical issues it has raised.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Indonesia Halts Military Ties to Australia Over Material It Deems Offensive
item.media:description: Australian and Indonesian soldiers training in Tully, Australia, in 2014. The countries have developed close military and economic relations.
item.description: Officials did not describe the material, which was found on an Australian base. The two countries are partners in the fight against terrorism.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY HUTTON and GERRY MULLANY

item.title: President Xi’s Great Chinese Soccer Dream
item.media:description: An 8-year-old practicing dribbling at the Evergrande Football School in Qingyuan, a city in southern China. Students swarm the fields nearly every day in an effort to achieve soccer glory.
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.description: Can a government initiative transform China’s lackluster soccer teams into World Cup contenders?
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Chinese City Official Shoots 2 Others and Kills Himself, State Media Says
item.description: An official with the land and resources bureau in a city in southwest China wounded the mayor and the Communist Party secretary at a meeting, news reports said.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY and ADAM WU

item.title: Sinosphere: Enough With the Tweets, China’s State Media Tells Trump
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump demonstrating how he uses Twitter in his office in Trump Tower in New York in 2015. He has jabbed at Beijing over Taiwan, trade, the South China Sea and, most recently, North Korea.
item.description: China has banned access to Twitter, but it is the country that President-elect Donald J. Trump seems to most enjoy taunting on his personal feed.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: In Turkey, U.S. Hand Is Seen in Nearly Every Crisis
item.media:description: A security officer outside the Reina nightclub in Istanbul on Wednesday.
item.description: Like the failed coup in July and the assassination of Russia’s ambassador in December, the New Year’s Day nightclub massacre is suspected of being a C.I.A. plot.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Philippines Jailbreak Frees More Than 150 Inmates, Prompting Manhunt
item.description: The overnight raid on a Mindanao jail killed a guard, and five escapees later died in a shootout. A bystander was also killed by mistake, the police said.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR

item.title: Editorial: An Exit Plan for Congo’s Kabila
item.media:description: Congolese bishops arriving for talks between the Kabila government and the opposition.
item.description: Holed up in his Kinshasa mansion, the president is still trying to wait out his enemies.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Editorial: China Joins the Fight to Save Elephants
item.description: The announcement of a halt to commercial ivory trade is welcome, but the ban needs to be enforced and other markets can’t be allowed to open.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.category: Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species

item.title: 15 of the Best Journals by Our Reporters Around the World
item.media:description: A man folding blankets that are rented out to the homeless in Delhi.
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.description: The conversational and visual on-the-ground reports offered a glimpse of captivating people and places, from a “sleep mafia” in Delhi to a monastery seeking salvation in beer.
item.dc:creator: Compiled by BARBARA TIERNEY

item.title: ‘I Didn’t Want to Lose My Identity’: 16,000 Readers Reflect on Their Surnames
item.media:description: Katherine Yuk from Toronto was one of more than 16,000 readers who responded when The New York Times asked women around the world why they kept or changed their surnames when they married.
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.description: The Times asked women around the world why they had kept or changed their surnames when they married. For many, the decision carried significant weight.
item.dc:creator: HANNA INGBER
